Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2012 08:29PM pooka wrote: Dear mari55, Thank you for your post.  To answer your question as to who is handling my care, the oncologist is.  He confers with the specialist when the medicine has to be changed due to progression in the bones.  I am going to give my onc another chance and ask for a DISCUSSION appointment and see how that goes.  I want to try to stay with this onc, but if the "Discussion appointment" doesn't work out I have to go to someone else.  I agree about the Zometa and this onc mentioned it last year and because I was uninformed, I said I didn't want it and the issue was dropped.  Now I really feel that he should have explained it more to me.  Thank you again.  You have been so helpful to me today and I am also now thinking about herceptin.  I will let you know what happens.

Posts.Title: I'm new here pooka pooka

Posts.Content: pooka wrote: Hello Everyone, I have been reading the posts on and off for a while now and I think that I need all of your help. I was diagnosed in 2009 with metastatic breast cancer that spread to the bone.  I received Femara for two  years and it stopped working, so on to Faslodex double shots.  Saw the onc yesterday after my scan and he said there is more progression in the bones.  NO ORGAN involvment.  (Yeah?)  While I was having the consultation with him he said that he had a call into the Specialist to decide whether to do one or two more rounds of Faslodex or to switch the medicine.  Now here comes the trickey part.  I asked him what is the medicine's name and he said it's too new it only has a number.  The Specialist did not call while I was there and my doctor told me that he would call me when he confered with him.  No phone call yet, as of this time.  He also mentioned to consider going on Zometa.  We had the Zometa conversation before and the first time he held off because he said that I was doing so well on the Femara.  The second conversation about Zometa that he brought up last year, I said that I read that it does not increase survival, therefore I didn't want it.  He said okay.  Now I think that he should have explained the Zometa a little more, and perhaps I would have had a different take on it last year. Okay, that's basically my story.  Please get me some input.  By the way, all of my blood work is normal, but my CA 27-29 is significantly higher.  That's how this consultation, that I requested happened yesterday.  When I called for the results of the blood work he only gave me the good blood numbers and I had to ask him for the CA 27-29 results, which I finally got the number yesterday.  On the phone he told me he didn't have it in front of him.  I asked for the Scan.  I was due for one anyway, this February.  That's another thing, we scan once a year.  I asked about that yesterday too.  I presented it as that I have heard that other women get scans more often.  His reply was, "You protested and were upset when I tried to talk to you about it."  I am so confused.  Please help. Dx 2/20/2009, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I'm new here pooka pooka

Posts.Content: pooka wrote: Hi everyone, I was all set to get a second opinion.  Went over and over it for days, since the visit to the oncologist last week.  Gathered the papers that were requested by the hospital, (I was missing one), and got a phone call from the caseworker at the hospital this a.m.  Okay, long story short, she said that I would also have to send over the slides from a pathology report of a bone marrow test that I had three years ago and the current films from the most recent CT scan.  Then she told me that if I am currently receiving treatment from my oncologist, the treatment would not be changed by them and would have to fail first before they would do anything for me.  She said it is that hospital's rule.  This to me sounds like I am bucking a system.  How do you get a new oncologist if you are being treated by the present one and the new one is waiting for your treatment to fail.  Did anyone run into this when they sought another opinion or changed doctors?  I think it would be easier to divorce my husband (NO I don't want to divorce my husband).  Please help.  Thank you. Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 06:07PM pooka wrote: Dear 33skidoo, I tried to get an appointment for a second opinion at Sloan Kettering and sent in the reports from the doctor that I already had.  Sloan asked for some additional slides and films which would not have been a problem.  Then Sloan told me that if I was in treatment by another oncologist, (he is not affliated with them) I could not get a second opinion from Sloan until my current treatment failed.  What kind of nonsense is this.  All I am taking is Tamoxifen.  My husband called MD Anderson just for infomation and they said that as long as I was not get a chemo and it was just Tamoxifen I could get a second opinion from MD Anderson.

Posts.Content: pooka wrote: Hi everybody.  I just want to get some input.  I'm mad as hell because I know that I have not taken advantage of my illness.  Yet, my husband tells me that I am "Using the Cancer Card" if I say that I have cancer.  I don't ask for special treatment from my husband or from anyone else.  I have been going along my way, doing as much as I can since I was diagnosed three years ago.  I do the housework, laundry and go out everyday to the store.  I don't understand why I have to even say to my husband that I have cancer, but sometimes when I am tired or really can't do something I remind him and he tells me that I am "Using the Cancer Card".  I asked him if he wanted me to lie and say that I didn't have it.  Am I missing something?  And you know something, so what if I am using the Cancer Card.  I don't think I am, but so what.  I feel so bad.   pooka Dx 2/20/2009, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 09:34PM pooka wrote: I don't know about Xeolda, but when I was getting Faslodex I could have picked up the medicine at the pharmacy, which I did not, because when I checked with Medicare, I was told that it would be covered under Part B, as long as it was an approved drug, ordered by the doctor and delivered to his office and administered by him.  That is the route that I took.  Medicare covered it and my secondary insurance picked up the rest.  If I picked up the medicine at the pharmacy it would have been covered under Part D (the prescription plan), but I would have had to pay quite a bit for it.  Check with Medicare to find out if Xeolda is covered under Part B.
